metadata.title: SUPPORTING INFORMATION Design, synthesis, and biological evaluation of potent thiosemicarbazone based cathepsin L inhibitors

location.addrLine: Robert Robinson Avenue, The Oxford Science Park
Robert Robinson Avenue, The Oxford Science Park

body_text.text: 2) Experimental procedure for the synthesis of Weinreb amides S4 -S10

3) Experimental procedure for the synthesis of ketones S11 -S20 4) Experimental procedure for the synthesis of thiosemicarbazones S21 -S38 5) Tables with standard errors S39 -S41 6) Cytotoxicity data and procedure S42 7) Cathepsins L and B assay procedures S43 -S44 8) Molecular Modeling experimental section S45 5) 1 H, 13 C, 19 F NMR, HPLC and LC-MS spectra for analog 1 S46 -S57

All reactions were performed under inert atmosphere using nitrogen gas unless specified differently. Chemicals reagents used in the synthetic procedures were obtained from various suppliers (Sigma Aldrich Chem. Co., Acros Chem. Co., Alfa Aesar, Fisher

Scientific, EMD Chemicals, and VWR). Silica gel (200 -400 mesh, 60Å) used for column chromatography was obtained from either Silicycle Inc or VWR. TLC plates (pre-coated glass plates with silica gel 60 F254, 0.25 mm thickness, EMD Chemicals, VWR) were used to monitor reactions. Intermediates and products synthesized were characterized based on 1 H-NMR (Varian operating at 500 MHz) and 13 C-NMR (Varian operating at 125 MHz). Deuterated CDCl 3 (with 0.03 % TMS as internal standard), Acetone-D 6, and DMSO-D 6 were used as common solvents for recording the NMR. All the chemical shifts are expressed in ppm (δ), coupling constants (J, Hz) and peak patterns are reported as broad (br), singlet (s), doublet (d), triplet (t), quartet (q) and multiplet (m).

Spectrometry Core Facility on a VG Prospec Micromass spectrometer using EI and Thermo Scientific LTQ Orbitrap Discovery using ESI. Purity of the compounds was further analyzed using an Agilent Technologies 1200 series HPLC system with a Diode Array and Multiple Wavelength Detector SL, equipped with an Agilent Eclipse XDB-C18 column (4.6 mm ID X 250mm (5 µm) 80 Å)), T = 30 o C; eluents solvent A, Water, solvent B, acetronitrile; gradient 80 % A 20 % B →74 % A 26 % B over 0 to 30 min; flow rate 1.5 mL/min; injection volume 20 μL; monitored at 300 and 320 nm wavelength.

The dyed protein was solubilized and absorbances were read with an automated microplate reader. A growth inhibition of 50% (GI 50 or the drug concentration causing a 50% reduction in net protein increase) was calculated from optical density data.

BIBREF6.title: Cells that had invaded through the Matrigel®, to the bottom of the insert, were fixed and stained with the Diff-Quick kit and the number of invaded cells was counted in four random fields under an inverted microscope. The invasion percentage was determined by dividing the number of cells that invaded the Matrigel® matrix by the number of cells
BIBREF6.venue: Control inserts contained only the 8 μm mesh without the Matrigel® coating

BIBREF7.title: Cathepsin B Assay for IC 50 Determination Human liver Cathepsin B (Calbiochem) was pre-incubated with inhibitors at various concentrations for 5 minutes at 37˚C. The assay was initiated by addition of substrate

BIBREF8.title: Arg-Arg-aminomethylcoumarin (Bacchem) and the final assay conditions were 1.1 nM cathepsin B, 60 µM Z-R-R-AMC, 126 mM sodium potassium phosphate pH 6

BIBREF10.title: The reaction was monitored a Thermo Fluoroskan Ascent FL microplate reader at excitation and emission filter wavelengths of 355 nm and 460 nm, respectively. Data were analyzed at 25˚C. The assay was initiated by addition of substrate Z-Phe-Arg-aminomethylcoumarin (Bacchem) and the final assay conditions were 1 nM cathepsin L, 50 µM Z-F-R-AMC, 100 mM sodium acetate
BIBREF10.venue: 0% DMSO (Acros). Inhibitors were serially diluted with DMSO and 0.01% Brij 35 to include a final concentration range of 20 µM to 10 pM

BIBREF11.title: Inhibitors were serially diluted with DMSO and water to include a final concentration range of 10 µM to 10 pM. The reaction was monitored fluorometrically for 5 minutes at 25˚C using black 96 well Corning 3686 assay microplates with a Thermo Fluoroskan Ascent FL microplate reader at excitation and emission filter wavelengths of 355 nm and 460 nm

FIGREF0.text: Fluoro-N-methoxy-N-methyl-benzamide (1a): 1 To a well-stirred suspension of N, Odimethylhydroxylamine hydrochloride (0.92 g, 9.49 mmol) in CH 2 Cl 2 (15 mL, Anhydrous) at 0 o C was added Et 3 N (1.7 mL, 12.76 mmol) dropwise. The reaction mixture was then stirred for 10 min at 0 o C, followed by the dropwise addition of 2fluorobenzoyl chloride (724 μL, 6.38 mmol) dissolved in CH 2 Cl 2 (5 mL, anhydrous). The reaction mixture was returned to room temperature and stirred for 3 h. The reaction mixture was quenched with water (25 mL) and the products were extracted with CH 2 Cl 2 (2 x 25 mL). The combined organic phases were washed with brine, dried over anhydrousNa 2 SO 4, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. Purification of the crude mixture by flash column chromatography (silica gel, hexanes:EtOAc, gradient 90:10 to 70:30) afforded the pure Weinreb amide (1a) (0.988 g, 5.39 mmol, 85 % yield) as a colorless oil. Characterization of Weinreb amide (1a) (R f = 0.25; 70:30; hexanes:EtOAc); 1 H-NMR (CDCl 3 , 500 MHz) δ 7.44 -7.37 (2H, m, ArH), 7.16 (1H, dt, J = 7.0 and 1.0 S5 N-Methoxy-2, N-dimethyl-benzamide (4a): 3 Acid chloride (1.00 g, 6.49 mmol) was treated with N, O-dimethylhydroxylamine hydrochloride (0.94 g, 9.73 mmol) following the general procedure used for compound (1a) to obtain Weinreb amide (4a) (1.09 g, 6.08 mmol, 94 % yield) as a colorless liquid. 1 H-NMR (CDCl 3 , 500 MHz) δ 7.30 -7.25 (2H, m, ArH), 7.21 -7.19 (2H, m, ArH), 3.50 (3H, brs, N-CH 3 ), 3.30 (3H, brs, O-CH 3 )

FIGREF9.text: Bromophenyl)-p-tolyl-methanone (29b):30  Weinreb amide (12a) (1 g, 5.58 mmol) was treated with 1,4-dibromobenzene(2.88 g, 12.77 mmol) to afford ketone (29b) (0.41 g, 1.49 mmol, 27 % yield) following the general procedure used for compound (1b). ,J. R. et al., J. Med. Chem., 1969, 12, 21.  30  Kangani, C. O. et al., Org. Lett., 2008, 10, 2645 S21 Experimental procedure for the synthesis of thiosemicarbazone derivatives: Bromophenyl)-(2-fluorophenyl)-ketone] thiosemicarbazone (1): A well-stirred solution of ketone (1b) (0.10 g, 0.36 mmol) in methanol (10 mL, anhydrous) was heated at reflux (70 o C). After 15 min, thiosemicarbazide (0.07 g, 0.72 mmol) and TsOH (10 mg) were added. After 8 h, water (10 mL) was added and the MeOH was removed under reduced pressure. Products were extracted in EtOAc (2 x 10 mL). The combined organic phases were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous Na 2 SO 4, and the solvent wasremoved under reduced pressure. Purification of the crude mixture by flash column chromatography (silica gel, hexanes:EtOAc, gradient 90:10 to 70:30) afforded the thiosemicarbazone derivative (1) (0.42 g, 0.12 mmol, 33 % yield) as a white solid. Characterization of thiosemicarbazone derivatives (1) (R f = 0.3; 70:30; hexanes:EtOAc). 1 H-NMR (CDCl 3 , 500 MHz) δ 9.09 (1H, brs, NH), 8.66 (1H, brs, NH), 8.55 (1H, brs, NH), 8.07 (1H, brs, ArH), 7.67 -7.64 (1H, m, ArH), 7.59 -7.57 (1H, m, ArH), 7.48 -7.43 (2H, m, ArH), 7.40 -7.37 (2H, m, ArH), 7.29 (1H, t, J = 8.0 Hz, ArH); 19 F-NMR (CDCl 3 , 470 MHz) δ -113.1 to -113.2 (1F, m, ArF); HRMS (EI) calcd for 350.9841, found 350.9833; HPLC retention time 12.16 min. [(4-Bromophenyl)-(4-fluorophenyl)-ketone] thiosemicarbazone (26): Commercially available ketone (0.20 g, 0.71 mmol) was treated with thiosemicarbazide (0.13 g, 1.43 mmol) to afford thiosemicarbazone (0.093 g, 0.26 mmol, 37 % yield) as a solid following the general procedure used for the compound (1). 1 H-NMR (CDCl 3 , 500 MHz) δ 8.60 (1H, brs, NH), 7.74 -7.72 (1H, m, ArH), 7.50 -7.47 (2H, m, ArH), 7.37 -7.34 (2H, m, ArH), 7.29 -7.26 (2H, m, ArH), 7.17 -7.16 (1H, m, ArH), 7.06 -7.03 (1H, m, ArH), 6.42 (1H, brs, NH); 19 F-NMR (CDCl 3 , 470 MHz) δ -108.2 to -108.3 (1F, m, ArF); HRMS (EI) calcd for 350.9841, found 350.9842; HPLC retention time 13.34 min. Bromo-phenyl)-p-tolyl-ketone[ thiosemicarbazone (30): Ketone (29b) (0.15 g, 0.54 mmol) was treated with thiosemicarbazide (0.10 g, 1.09 mmol) to afford thiosemicarbazone (0.062 g, 0.18 mmol, 33 % yield) as a solid following the general procedure used for the compound (1). 1 H-NMR (CDCl 3 , 500 MHz) δ 8.69 (1H, brs, NH), 7.72 -7.71 (1H, m, ArH), 7.48 -7.46 (2H, m, ArH), 7.39 -7.37 (4H, m, ArH), 7.17 -7.13 (2H, m, ArH), 6.46 (1H, brs, NH), 2.45 (3H, s, CH 3 ); HRMS (EI) calcd for 347.0092, found 347.0084; HPLC retention time 14.67 min. FIGREF12.text: compounds 1, 5, and 6 on the ability of DU-145 cells to invade the Matrigel® matrix according to the manufacturer's protocol (Becton Dickinson, Bedford, MA). Briefly, Matrigel®-coated 8 μm mesh inserts were rehydrated with the appropriate culture media for 1-2 h at room temperature after which they were transferred to 24 well plates containing the appropriate serum free media. Five hundred microliters of cell suspension containing 5×104 cells were added to each well and the cells were incubated in the presence of 20 µM of each compound and E-64 as a positive control for 24 h. For these experiments, the lower invasion chambers contained media with 10% fetal bovine serum 32 (a) Sriram, M.; Hall, J. J.; Grohmann, N. C.; Strecker, T. E.; Wootton, T.; Franken, A.; Trawick, M. L.; Pinney, K. G. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2008, 16, 8161. (b) Monks, A.; Scudiero, D.; Skehan, P.; Paull, K.; Vistica, D.; Hose, C.; Langley, J.; Cronise, P.; Vaigro-Wolf, A. J. Natl. Caner Inst. 1991, 83, 757 (c) Vichai, V.; Kirtikara, K. Nat. Protocols 2006, 1, 1112.

Inhibition of human cathepsins L and B by difluoro-substituted benzophenone thiosemicarbazone derivatives 34 to 36.S41 a E/Z isomer not assigned, b 2 % DMSO, c 0.7 % DMSO, NA = Not applicable Note: Cathepsin L is especially sensitive to DMSO concentration therefore data has been standardized throughout the manuscript to 2 % DMSO; however 0.7 % DMSO data isTable 5. Cytotoxicity, invasion and migration for analogs 1, 5, and 6. Relative to normalized control, ND = Not determined Cytotoxicity assay: Inhibition of human cancer cell line growth was assessed using the National Cancer Institute's standard sulforhodamine B (SRB) assay. 32 Briefly, cells in the appropriate culture media supplemented with 5% fetal bovine serum were inoculated into 96-well plates and incubated for 24 h. Serial dilutions of the compounds were then added.

back_matter.text: The crystal structure of two cathepsin L molecules complexed with thyroglobulin type-1 (PDB code 1ICF) was used as the starting point for the modeling study. Structure manipulation and visualization were carried out in Insight II 2005 (Accelrys, San Diego, CA). The missing residues, Glu-176, Ser-177 and Asp-178 (cathepsin L numbering) were inserted and a single cathepsin L molecule was extracted. Initially, crystallographic water molecules buried in the mature enzyme were retained. Hydrogen atoms were added, and the pH was set to 5.5. Both N and C termini of the protein were in the ionized state with the histidine-163 side-chain as the imidazolium cation. The catalytic side-chain of cysteine-25 was modeled as a thiolate anion. The cathepsin L backbone was tethered and the complex was subjected to conjugate gradient energy minimization and molecular dynamics using a fixed dielectric function and the CVFF force field. This complex served as the template for the initial docking of our inhibitors.Bound conformations of the inhibitors were modeled by docking them according to the template followed by a conformational search using a Monte Carlo minimization (MCM) procedure using the Affinity module. Starting structures for each cycle of minimization were obtained by randomly perturbing one or more dihedral angles in the inhibitor.Perturbations involving random changes in the side chain dihedral angles as well as crankshaft rotations were carried out. Residues of the protein around the active site including the S3´-S3 subsites, were allowed to relax during the minimization.Monte Carlo minimizations of cathepsin L -inhibitor complexes were collected in groups of 200 and examined for hydrogen bonding, total energy, interaction energy, and distances of inhibitor atoms from the Cys-25 thiolate, among other parameters, and then ranked by the interaction energies. The inhibitors with the best interaction energies and best Cys-25 thiolate-thiocarbonyl carbon (inhibitor) distances were selected for further evaluation by manual visualization.
